talk.start.para: - I wish to ask the Vice-President of the Executive Council a question without notice. I understand that the first business to be considered to-day is the second reading of the Northern Territory Acceptance Bill. I notice on one of the walls of the chamber a large map, which, I presume, has been placed there for the information of honorable senators. If that be so, it ought to be an accurate map. As a matter of fact, it is not an accurate map. It shows the railway line from Townsville to Cloncurry as going through Winton, when, as a matter of fact, the line does not go through Winton, or pass near that town at all. I notice, also, that the map is not drawn to scale. I should like to know by whose authority so inaccurate a map has been placed here for the information of honorable members?

- In answer to the honorable senator's question, I may say that I did not draw the map. I may add that even the accuracy of the Ten Commandments is sometimes disputed. I shall make all inquiries necessary to see that any irregularities in the map referred to are explained.

debate.para: Bill presented, and read a first time.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10th August (vide page 1313), on motion by Senator McGregor -

quote.para: That this Bill be now read a second time.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - As I moved the adjournment of the debate after Senator McGregor had moved the second reading of this Bill, it devolves upon me to say a few words upon it. I think there is no difference of opinion as to the desirability of the Commonwealth taking over the Northern Territory. It comprises an area of nearly 600,000 square miles, and is a very large and practically uninhabited portion of Australia. It has many valuable rivers, and there are places on the coast at which a foreign Power might obtain ingress and secure a foothold in positions from which it would probably involve a vast deal of trouble and expense to dislodge an enemy. The subject-matter of the Bill is covered by the terms of the agreement under which we are invited to take possession of this Territory. Honorable senators will bear in mind that, although South Australia has had control of the Northern Territory for a great number of years, she has never been able to make a success of the task she undertook in the government of it, although she has spent a great deal of money in the effort to develop it.
- She has kept it white, and has not, as has been done by some of the States with their territory, attempted to develop it with black labour.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I believe that, as a matter of fact, there are more Chinese than Europeans in the Northern Territory, so that South Australia has not kept it white. The principal business residents are yellow coloured men. However, the population is a purely negligible quantity.
- The coloured people have left it because they could not live in it; even the Chinamen have gone out of it.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The Northern Territory forms a not inconsiderable portion of Australia, and South Australia has incurred an annual loss by the ordinary expenditure in its development. The Vice-President of the Executive Council, in introducing the Bill, cited the cost of the construction of the railway from Port Darwin to Pine Creek. The public debt on the Territory amounts to something like , £2,725,000, and the deficit on the advance account is £603,222. These figures represent the state of affairs about twelve months ago, but they are the latest I could get. This brings the present debt on the Territory to about £3,300,000. I wish honorable senators to notice particularly that the deficit represents the annual loss involved in the control of the Territory by South Australia. The interest payable upon loans amounts to £110,990 per annum, and if the Commonwealth takes over the Territory, it must become responsible for the deficit and the annual expenditure by way of interest. There is a further interest charge on the advance account of £602,222 amounting annually to £17,142. Under the agreement included in this Bill, it is stipulated that there shall be a sinking fund provided by the Commonwealth. I believe that South Australia makes provision for a sinking fund in respect of the debt of £2,725,000 to which I have referred, and it is estimated that this involves an annual charge of £6,963. These figures of interest payable and provision for sinking fund amount together to £135,000. Then it is proposed that there shall be a sinking fund in connexion with the smaller sum due, and this will make an addition of a further amount to the annual expenditure. Then there is an excess of interest and sinking fund in the accounts for 1907-8 of £16,398. There is a total annual expenditure upon the Territory, not including interest on the Oodnadatta railway, of £151,493. As to the Oodnadatta railway, of which we are asked to take charge, we find that it has cost South Australia £2,242,600, and that the annual interest amounts to £84,000. There is a surplus of earnings over working expenses of £12,000.
- How do they get at that? Does that mean £12,000 per annum, or for the whole period ?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The annual surplus of revenue over earnings amounts to £12,000, leaving a net deficit of £72,000 upon the railway. The Commonwealth is asked to indemnify South Australia for the expenditure to which she has been put on that account. Furthermore, under the proposed agreement, the Commonwealth is to be bound to connect the railway from Port Augusta to Oodnadatta with the line from Port Darwin to Pine Creek. The cost of that work has been estimated at nearly £5,000,000 sterling; so that, as the Vice-President of the Executive Council put it the other day, we are called upon to face an expenditure of between £10,000,000 and £11,000,000 sterling in connexion with this agreement.
- And in return for that the Commonwealth will get an area four times as large as Great Britain.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - It has been stated that the area is so large that the total cost works out at something like 3d. an acre. But 1 want honorable senators to realize that we are not buying the Territory. We are called upon to take charge of it in the interest of the whole of Australia.
- It is being given to us !

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - It is not being given, nor is it being bought by us. Originally South Australia was, by charter, intrusted with the control and management of the Territory, the right of the Crown being reserved to revoke the grant at any time. The Territory was not given to South Australia to form a part of her own property in the ordinary sense of the term. It was merely placed under her control and administration. In the Commonwealth Constitution it is, however, recognised as being a portion of South Australia. But now South Australia comes to the Commonwealth with a proposal in which she says that she is quite willing to hand over to us the control of the Territory on certain conditions. One condition is that she shall be indemnified for the expenditure to which she has been put, and the loss she has sustained, in connexion with the administration.
-That is not unreasonable.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I quite agree with the honorable senator. I do not suppose that there is a single member in either House of the Legislature who would demur for one moment to that proposition. It is generally recognised that South Australia has acted as a trustee, and has administered the Territory to the best of her ability at considerable outlay. We are prepared, as we ought to be, to recognise that as a fair and reasonable proposal. But when we come to consider the other provisions of the agreement, we find ourselves hampered with conditions which we should find it hard to justify in the interests of the Commonwealth. We ought not to permit ourselves to be leg-roped - to use an expression employed in this Chamber on a previous occasion - in the matter of connecting the Northern Territory with other portions of Australia. We ought not to be compelled of necessity to construct the railway that South Australia considers to be the proper one.
- It is the proper one, beyond a doubt.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator, as a representative of South Australia, is entitled to think so.
- No one questions that. The only thing is that the projected railway would not develop Queensland territory.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Perhaps New South Wales would support Queensland in that contention. If the route proposed by South Australia will stand the test of examination and determination by the governing power, why should she be afraid to trust this Parliament ? . But, on the other hand, if it is shown that the proper way to develop the Territory by building a railway through it is to take the line over to the east, and attach it to the States of Queensland and New South Wales, the Commonwealth ought not to hesitate to adopt that course.
- And develop Queensland instead.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I do not think that Queensland desires the Commonwealth to help in the development of her territory. She has always shown an independent attitude, and has been well able to develop her own lands, and is doing so at a rapid rate at present. But my argument is not that we ought to develop Queensland, South Australia, or any other State by means of the projected railway, but that the railway ought to be for the purpose of developing the Northern Territory, and making it, what we believe it may ultimately be, a very fine area for the settlement of a large number of people, whom we hope to see placed there. If it were shown that the best route for the railway would be towards the east instead of north and south as South Australia desires, we should carry the line in that direction so that we might develop the Territory to the highest advantage. The descriptions of the Territory that have been furnished to us seem to me to show that there are large areas of valuable land lying to the east of the proposed line of railway, and not to the west, nor along a direct north and south route. If the line be carried north and south, it will traverse a large tract of barren, useless country, but if it were carried to the east there might be a possibility of developing valuable land. South Australia, however, has devoted time, energy, and money to the development of the Northern Territory, and she may think that she ought to be recouped for her expenditure by the construction of a railway which would connect Port Darwin with South Australia proper. But our main object must be to develop the Northern Territory itself. The only question for us is whether the railway which South Australia desires would have the effect of developing the richest portion of the land.
- Yes, of course.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - But the reports which I have read show that the richest territory is to be found towards the east instead of along a due north and south route.
- Nothing of the kind.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Of course, I have not been in the Territory itself, and can only speak from reports which I have read.
- Will the honorable senator indicate one report that condemns the route of the proposed railway, which includes the MacDonnell Ranges?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I have not the reports by me just now, and do not know that I could put my finger immediately on the passages to which I refer; but I have read them, and the impression strongly formed in my mind is that the most valuable country lies to the east. I do not say that there is no valuable land along the due north and south route; but I am satisfied that there is a greater possibility of development in an easterly direction than is probable by taking the other route. Again, it may be remembered that Lord Kitchener, on his re cent visit to Australia, called attention to the necessity of connecting the Northern Territory with the other portions of Australia by railway. Let us, therefore, look at the matter from a military point of view for a few minutes. If it be necessary that a line of railway should be built to the Northern Territory in order to protect it from any attempted raid in time of war, where would the bulk of the troops for the defence of the Territory be drawn from ? Would they not be drawn from the eastern coasts of Australia? Do we not find, when we consider the facts, that the largest number of troops could most expeditiously be despatched from Queensland and New South Wales, rather than from the south ? Evidently, the bulk of the troops must come from the portions of Australia where the bulk of the population resides. The bulk of the population is on the eastern seaboard.
- At Sydney, of course !

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - No; not necessarily at Sydney. I am not speaking from the point of view of Queensland, Victoria, or New South Wales, no matter what the honorable senator may think.
- Does not the honorable senator contemplate the possibility of all the States being connected with the main line?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Yes; but when we are talking about railway construction we must remember that the resources of the Commonwealth are not unlimited. Do honorable senators think for a moment that the Commonwealth would be justified in building any but the line of railway that it would be most advantageous to construct, both from the point of view of military strategy and territorial development ? We also have to bear in mind that the railways which South Australia has at present built in and to the Territory do not pay, and, as far as I can judge, will not pay. South Australia is asking us to incur a heavy liability in taking over these lines. If, therefore, she insists on our building a line which is not the most advantageous to construct, and we do so, the Commonwealth will be saddled with a still greater probable loss, whilst, at the same time, we may not have the line which will best conduce to development in the future. Does South Australia believe that the Commonwealth can develop the Territory properly and fairly, or does she consider that the Commonwealth requires her Government at its back to advise in what way it is to develop its own land?
- South Australia thinks that the Commonwealth ought to be guided by the hand of the State, which has already failed.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - We have to realize that South Australia has failed to make a success of the Territory, and that, so far as we can judge, there is no prospect of her doing any better in the years to come. If she felt that she could develop the Territory to her own advantage and at her own expense, do honorable senators think for a moment that she would have offered it to the Commonwealth ?
- If you reject this agreement, you will see what she will do.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: -We have heard that statement before. South Australia has had forty years in which to develop the Territory, and she has succeeded in building a little railway line and piling up not only a large loan debt, but also an annually recurring deficit of about £110,000.
- And New South Wales had 100 years in which to develop her territory.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - New South Wales never attempted to develop the Territory. She never undertook the control of it.
- She had control of it.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: .- New South Wales never attempted to develop the Territory. I give South Australia all credit for the pluck and energy which' she has displayed; but, unfortunately, she has failed to achieve the success which she desired. An interjection was made just now with regard to the valuable country in the Macdonnell Ranges. It was suggested not long ago that, instead of South Australia handing over to the Commonwealth the Northern Territory down to her present northern boundary, she might hand over only the portion of the Territory north of the Macdonnell Ranges, leaving the ranges in her hands if she believes that they are capable of being developed and made a profitable proposition. I feel quite sure that a Bill for that purpose would receive acceptance at the hands of honorable senators. I do not know whether Senator Symon agrees with the view expressed that there is nothing in the agreement to bind the Commonwealth to carry the railway entirely within the Territory or to prevent the Commonwealth from diverting it into the neighbouring States, so long as it touches on the northern boundary of South Australia. That view has been put forward, I believe, by a member of the present Government. But, on the other hand, we have had placed upon the table the opinion of the Crown Solicitor for South Australia, in which he advised his Government that the railway must be constructed within the Territory, and that' it would be a breach of the agreement to deflect it into either of the adjoining States.
- The honorable senator knows that we can always get any persons but the lawyers to agree.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Honorable senators have to bear in mind that they are now asked to assent to an agreement. It is an important consideration to them whether it bears one construction or the other. Therefore it is most desirable that they should give attention te the point.
- Make it. clear.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - It may be desirable to make it clear, so that honorable senators may know what they are doing. If the agreement does provide that the whole of the railway must be constructed within the Northern Territory, how foolish the Parliament would be if it acted on the assumption that it had the right to go into the adjoining States, only to find itself at- last haled before the High Court for attempting to do what was unconstitutional.
- Apart from the constitutional or legal aspect, there ought to be no question of sharp dealing in the matter.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Exactly. I am not going to charge anybody with an attempt of that kind, because one opinion is supplied by the Commonwealth law officers, and another opinion is provided, for public consumption, by the law authorities of South Australia. While the matter remains in doubt, the Senate should take the course necessary to protect the interests of all parties, and that is not to bind the Commonwealth to construct the railway in any particular direction. It is not right, I repeat, to attempt to shackle the Commonwealth in any way with regard to the administration of the affairs of the Territory. It should be left with a free Hand, and should the present Government be in power when it became necessary to build' the railway, no doubt they would select the route which they conceived to be best in the interests of the Territory and of the Commonwealth as a whole, regardless of whether it might be to the advantage or to the detriment of a particular city or State. The agreement, of course, contains a large number of conditions. I am prepared to accept the broad condition that the Commonwealth shall recoup South Australia for any loss which she may have sustained in connexion with the railway, but neither my voice nor my vote will be given in favour of placing any restrictive conditions upon the Commonwealth in regard to the way in which it is to develop the Territory. If South Australia thinks that the Commonwealth is capable of developing the Territory, she should say, " Go and do the best you can with it." We have only one object to serve, and that is to promote the interests of the Commonwealth as a whole, and not of any particular portion of it.
- Besides, in any future arrangement made, South Australia, in common with the other States, would have its full say.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - South Australia has a constitutional right to make her voice heard in this Chamber. She has always had the great advantage of being represented by many singularly able men, who have been enabled to clearly state her position whenever it became necessary, in contradistinction to the position of other portions of the Commonwealth, and so far as one can judge she will probably continue to return that class of legislators. I have no desire to say more at this stage. I have no doubt that the second reading of the Bill will be carried on the voices, but I would urge honorable senators either to eliminate from the agreement the portions which tie up the Commonwealth, or to add a proviso which would make it absolutely clear and plain that the Parliament of the Commonwealth is to be the sole and final arbiter as to the way in which the Territory shall be developed.

- I do not think that any of us, and certainly not those who are more intimately connected with South Australia, have any reason to complain of the initial attitude which my honorable friend, Senator Gould, took in the view which he with so much force placed before the Senate; nor do I think that there is any dispute that from the broad, national standpoint, it is desirable, in the interests of the Commonwealth as a whole, that this great tract of country, which is almost one-fifth of the area of Australia, should be directly under the control of the Commonwealth. I do not, and never did consider, that it is any objection to the attitude of South Australia - although there has been a good deal of carping criticism to that effect - that she has not succeeded in making the Northern Territory populous, or, so to speak, blossom as a rose, rich with the produce of the undoubted mineral wealth which it possesses. I am not at all sure that the other States have quite overtaken all the development which is possible within their boundaries. I am one of those who are inclined to think that some of the larger States might very well be divided, that those portions which they are unable to effectively control might very well be declared Territories of the Commonwealth, and that when they reach that stage of population and wealth which would entitle them to be regarded as States, they should be admitted as States of the Commonwealth. Therefore, I do not attach the slightest importance to criticism such as. that which my honorable friend has just used in respect to South Australia not having made a success of the Territory. Success is a vague term, and success within the meaning of what I have indicated has not been possible for a population of 300,000 or 400,000, who, to use a common expression, have perhaps " bitten off more than they can chew."
- They have done remarkably well.

- I think, so. That is the position. It is of no use to make a statement like that of my honorable friend, that South Australia has not made a success of the Territory for forty years, although it has been in her possession. But for the fact that she was exercising the functions of government, and controlling the Territory, it is just possible that it might not have been in the possession of Australia at the present moment. No reproaches ought to be cast on any State. I am not sure that reproaches could not be cast on New South Wales or Queensland for having, I will not say neglected, but ineffectively developed the immense areas which they respectively possess, and that they might not have been made much more productive of wealth than they have been; but that is no reproach.

speech.para: People forget that this great continent is very nearly as large as the whole of Europe, which contains fourteen or fifteen nations, and to use it as a reproach or as an objection to an agreement or a bargain of this character, that South Australia, with her 300,000 or 400,000 people, has not done all that she might or could have done, is simply to utter, I shall not call it claptrap, as it comes from my honorable friend, whom I esteem very much, but remarks which are utterly beside the question with which we are concerned.

talk.start.para: - The remarks were made not so much to carp at South Australia, as to point out the difficulty in front of the Commonwealth. In other words, to point out that the Territory is not such a valuable asset as is represented.

- That does not show that it is not a valuable asset. Western Australia was called the Cinderella of the Continent a few years ago, and nobody knew of the existence of those untold golden riches which were under her soil some 300 or 400 miles from the coast, until they were discovered. I dare say that if anybody had suggested, when she had a population of some 40,000 or 50,000 persons, that that enormous territory - about a fifth of the whole continent - should be taken over as part of a bargain, it would have been stated that all the country at Kalgoorlie and Coolgardie was a mere barren desert, and would not provide water for a goat within hundreds of miles. But look at it now. So in the Northern Territory it is the same at this day, but it is the same with this difference, that it has been established that it is immensely rich in mineral wealth.
- Why not keep it then?

speech.para: Senator Sir JOSIAH SYMON.Because we want to generously share it with the other States. The honorable senator is like others who desire to have the Northern Territory annexed to Queensland, to have all its riches in the possession of that State, and its produce brought down to Brisbane, always subject, of course, to the claims of some of my honorable friends from Sydney, who think that that is the port to which the produce of the Territory should come. I do not intend :to occupy the attention of the Senate on the question of the desirability and importance of the Territory being an integral part of the Commonwealth as a Territory, and not as part of the State of South Australia.

Senator Gould was quite right in saying that there is no difference of opinion on the broad national question of the desirability of taking over the Territory. 1 do not believe there is a member of the Senate who holds a different opinion. Nor is there any difference of opinion that the Territory, if it is taken over by the Commonwealth, should be transferred subject to the charge upon it.

talk.start.para: - That is not in question at all.

- Just so. But it was, I think, in question not long ago. People used to say, " We ought not to pay South Australia this money," and I could not understand the contention. Because, as between man and man, if a property is handed over from one to another for a consideration, or without it, in addition to the charges due upon it, it is taken over subject to the mortgage, if any, upon it ; and the debt on the Territory may be described as a mortgage. I could never understand the suggestion made, and I am glad that no such suggestion is now made, that the Territory should not be taken over subject to the charges upon it, incurred by the owner in doing his duty by it. That is now conceded. But one reason why, from another point of view, that is fair and proper, is that South Australia has expended these moneys in building railways with a view to the development of the Territory. . She built the Port Darwin to Pine Creek railway, and has run it all these years, if not at a loss, at any rate without much profit. Honorable senators, perhaps, forget that she has also run a railway from Port Augusta up to Oodnadatta, which is within 100 miles of the 26th parallel, the southern boundary of the Territory. So that South Australia has done a very great deal in the direction of carrying out what, adopting a phrase used by Senator Gould, is best adapted in the interests of the Commonwealth to promote the development of the Territory in the future, namely, the construction of a direct line from Port Augusta to Pine Creek and Port Darwin. The debt on the Territory has been incurred in this way, and in the necessary efforts of South Australia to work the southern railway until she could connect Oodnadatta with Pine Creek. When it is remarked that South Australia has not been successful in developing the Territory, it might be said that she was not successful because of the policy of keeping Australia white.
- That stands to her everlasting credit.

- She had an opportunity a good many years ago, and passed an Act to avail herself of that opportunity, for the introduction of Indian coolies into the Northern Territory. But the sentiment of South Australia, and of Australia generally, was so strong as to the desirability of keeping Australia white that that Act remained a dead letter, and not a single coolie from India was imported under it into the Northern Territory. It is all very well for honorable senators to say that the Chinese are there; but I may say that, but for them, there would be no revenue at all from the Territory, and that is not the only part of Australia in which there are Chinese. South Australia abstained from introducing coolies to develop the Territory. Another thing from which she abstained was the opportunity to continue the line from Oodnadatta to Pine Creek by securing its construction on the land-grant system, as she might have done more than once during the last forty years. I say that that is something to be proud of also. It is another of the circumstances which account for the accumulation of the debt.
- The honorable senator thinks that the people of South Australia should be rewarded because they refrained from doing wrong things.
- The honorable senator would never be rewarded if he were only to be rewarded when he refrained from doing wrong things.
- That is the honorable senator's argument.

- Not at all. I am dealing with the matter from a national point of view. I am sure that my honorable friend's policy is to keep Australia white, and to abstain from the construction of railways on the land-grant system.
- Yes, but I say that no. one has a right to claim a reward for refraining from doing wrong things.
- What reward ?
- South Australia claims a reward under this Bill!

- South Australia is not asking the Commonwealth to do this, and, instead of getting a reward, it appears to me that she is likely to get more kicks than ha'pence. This is part of a bargain. My honorable friends keep on saying that South Australia is asking the Commonwealth to pass this Bill and to do this, that, and the other. She is doing nothing of the kind. This is a mutual bargain between two contracting parties, the Commonwealth on the one hand, and the State of South Australia, the present owner of the Territory, on the other.
- And a huckstering bargain at that.

- It is on the part of the Commonwealth ; and my honorable friend is intensifying its huckstering character, it seems to me. It is conceded on all hands that South Australia, in transferring this Territory to the Commonwealth, is entitled to be paid the money expended and resting as a charge upon it. If that is conceded as a right, what consideration is she getting for parting with the Territory?
- She is asking us to take over a non-paying railway.
- The Territory represents a dead loss to her every year.
- One thing at a time. I say, on this point, that South Australia is not getting a ha'porth of reward for her forty years' control of the Territory.
- Except to be recouped for all her losses in connexion with it.

- That is not a reward. She is proposing to give the Commonwealth many times the value of that. If we put the matter on that ground, let me remind honorable senators that South Australia is giving the Commonwealth 335,000,000 acres of land at 2d. per acre.
- Does the honorable senator regard the Northern Territory as an asset ?
- To the Commonwealth ?
- To anybody.
- Yes.
- I regard it as a liability.
- Then the honorable senator's judgment on that point is not sound.
- The figures prove it.
- They do not prove anything of the kind. The Ministry of which my honorable friend was a member introduced a Bill identical with this, last year, and proposed to give us the railways also.
- Political exigencies.
- I do not care what the honorable senator calls it ; there are strange names for these things.
- Was the Bill of last year on the same lines as this?

- It was exactly the same as this Bill. I do not suppose that anything I could say, or anything that an angel from Heaven could say, would satisfy honorable senators from Queensland, or, perhaps, some of our honorable friends from New South Wales, that the straightest line from north to south is not to be found by going 1,000 miles to the east, and zigzagging the line to the south. They say that the longest way round is the shortest way home.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: - It very often is.

speech.para: Senator Sir JOSIAH SYMON.Perhaps; but it is not so with regard to this particular railway. Putting all that on one side, I say that, so far as regards the taking over of the Territory on the one hand, and accepting the liability on the other, there is not one ha'porth of reward proposed for South Australia. She would not make one farthing of profit out of the bargain. We are all agreed upon that. Rut do honorable senators not think that she is entitled to make some little profit out of it?

talk.start.para: - I thought the honorable senator was dealing with the question from a great national point of view.

- I am bringing it down, for a moment, to my honorable friend's suggested huckstering level. Will any one say that 335,000,000 acres, with Port Darwin and its harbor, are not worth more than 2d. per acre?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: - To make anything out of the Territory we shall have to spend a good deal more.
- Suppose we have a naval base in Sydney, does not my honorable friend think that a little of the revenue of the Northern Territory will be spent there?
- There will be no revenue. We shall have to meet a deficit.
- We are going to make revenue.
- How?
- When my honorable friend is Prime Minister of the Commonwealth, which, we hope, will be soon.
- I thought the honorable senator would not answer the question.
- When Leader of the Senate, Senator Millen voted for the Bill.
- That is not strictly correct; but, perhaps, it is as near as the honorable senator could possibly get.

- It is as near as is necessary; but I shall not quarrel with Senator Millen if he changes his opinion. I merely wish to say that South Australia will not make a single farthing out of this transaction, unless by the stipulation agreed to by both the contracting parties with respect to the railway. That is really the question on which we differ. I wish to remind my honorable friend, when he talks about distances, that South Australia has bridged over the distance between Port Augusta and the southern boundary of the Territory to within100 miles. She also, years ago - and I think this stands to her credit in connexion with the development of the Territory, as well as in connexion with national Australian interests - built the telegraph line across the continent. Honorable senators need not imagine for a moment that, in making these references, I am boasting of what South Australia has done. What I mean to infer is that, if this Bill is not passed - and I am not saying this as a threat in any shape or form - I have faith that South Australia, in some way, will accomplish her destiny in connexion with the Northern Territory, and will, whether by the land grant or some other system, construct the railway, and bridge over the distance between Oodnadatta and Pine Creek before many years are past. Personally, I do not care two pins whether the Senate adopts the agreement or does not ; but I say that South Australia, which has done so much in the construction of national works of benefit to Australia, is capable of doing more. I ask honorable senators to recollect that she has already constructed, at her own expense, the railway which it is a part of this agreement that the Commonwealth should take over. The coot of that railway is a present charge on the Territory which should be paid back to South Australia if it is transferred to the Commonwealth. It should not be forgotten that the railways already constructed bridge over the worst part of the intervening territory between the good country on the south and the good country to the north. I should like to see any report which condemns the MacDonnell Range country, or the country from the Katherine River northwards. It is magnificent country.
- What is the rainfall?
- I have not examined the statistical records of the rainfall. My honorable friend can examine and analyze them as much as he pleases.
- The honorable senator wishes people to know nothing of reports of an unsatisfactory kind.

- If my honorable friend lives in the statistics of the rainfall, I give him joy of it. I may be allowed to say that the arguments with respect to distance, in connexion with military operations, appear to me to be ludicrous. The populous State of Victoria is practically within from twelve to fifteen hours of Port Augusta. If they were wanted, troops could be sent from Melbourne to Port Augusta, and from there on to Port Darwin in much shorter time than by any other route. That, as every one knows, is the shortest route to Port Darwin from Melbourne, and is shorter by perhaps 200 or 300 miles than the shortest of the zig-zag routes which have been suggested.
- Not zig-zag ; what is proposed is a slight deviation.

- A slight deviation which, no doubt, would be almost unobservable on a map on which 100 miles would seem as one. A slight deviation into Queensland is proposed; and God alone knows when we should ever get out of the State again.
- It is proposed that the line should almost immediately leave the Northern Territory.

- Of course it is. I do not wish to say a word against the desirability of linking up existing lines of railway communication with the Northern Territory line. I hope, and believe, that that will be done some day ; but it should be done at the expense of the States most concerned.
- But the Commonwealth should bear the expense of linking up South Australia with the Northern Territory ?

- There are already constructed two most important sections of the great trunk line linking up South Australia with Port Darwin, and all that is asked, under this Bill, is that we should bridge over the gap between Oodnadatta and Pine Creek.

- If the Northern Territory is to belong to the Commonwealth, why should we go beyond the boundaries of our own Territory to construct a railway in South Australia, if we ought not to go into the other States for the same purpose?

- We are making a bargain with South Australia now ; and the railway already constructed' must be regarded, from an ordinary business point of view, as a part of the main trunk line. It would seem to be merely a sensible thing that we should utilize the two portions of the main trunk line already constructed, and content ourselves with closing up the gap between them. Why should we abandon a railway which goes to within 100 miles of the border of the Territory to be taken over, in order to get away to the east to make a slight deviation, as Senator Fraser says, into Queensland or New South Wales?
- Who proposes that we should go to the east, or in any other direction ?
- We need not go in any other direction. We can keep the railway within the Territory and South Australia.
- Who proposes to go anywhere else?
- The honorable senator.

- I do not propose anything of the sort. I propose that if the Territory is taken over by the Commonwealth, this Parliament shall be left absolutely free to do what is best for the development of the Territory.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: - Hear, hear !

- Senator Gould cheers the interjection by Senator Givens. Both these gentlemen are taking the broad, national view, and propose to take advantage of what they consider the necessities of South Australia, to despoil her of any future results from her efforts. I must say that patriotism in New South Wales and Queensland is gradually increasing.
- Has not the honorable senator ample faith in the Federal Parliament?

- I have ample faith in the Federal Parliament, but we are now making a bargain. The Commonwealth desires, I take it, to be possessed of this Territory, which, as it exists, is a menace to the safety of Australia. The

speech.para: Commonwealth was the initiator of this project. She approached South Australia, and asked that State on what terms she would be prepared to hand over the Territory. South Australia replies, ' ' All that we desire is that you will complete the grand trunk railway, which' we have already begun, through to Port Darwin." That is all ; and that, as far as I am concerned, I hold to. I shall decline to be a party to handing over the Northern Territory to the Commonwealth unless it be part of the bargain that the Commonwealth shall construct that trunk line between the north and south. I am quite willing, as far as the route is concerned, that it shall be anywhere within 500 or 600 miles east or west of the twenty-sixth parallel. I am quite willing that the best route shall be ascertained within the area. But, speaking for myself, I will not depart from the condition that the railway must be wholly within the Northern Territory. There is one point as to which I agree with my honorable friend, Senator Gould, and that is that there seems to be a little ambiguity as to whether the language of this Bill would permit the line to deviate into Queensland or New South Wales, or out of the Northern Territory. I am glad that Senator Gould has called attention to the point. I consider that it should be made perfectly clear. If honorable senators desire to vote for this Bill on the assumption that the stipulation in question shall be satisfied by taking the railway eastward into Queensland or New South Wales, the Bill ought clearly to say so. On the' other hand, if they desire that the railway should be wholly within the Northern Territory, the Bill should say so.

talk.start.para: - Does not the honorable senator think that it would be a good thing to allow the Commonwealth Parliament to decide that point?

- We are not here to pass a Bill merely to provide a cause of litigation between South Australia and the Commonwealth. Last year it was stated over and over again what the intention was, and we all voted for the Bill on the assumption that the line was to be wholly within the Northern Territory. It was so declared by Mr. Groom, then Minister of External Affairs, in the House of Representatives. He was asked by Mr. W. H. Irvine, when he was moving the second rending of the Bill, " One terminal point is Pine Creek; what is the other ? " Mr. Groom said, " A point anywhere on the

speech.para: Port Augusta line. The real terminal points are Port Augusta and Port Darwin." Then, when the point was put more specifically by Mr. W. H. Irvine, " Under this agreement, will the whole of the railway have to be within the Northern Territory? " Mr. Groom said, " That is so, according to the strict interpretation of the agreement; but the South Australian Government take a more liberal view, and contemplate the possibility of having to cross the Queensland border." That is a matter of concession, which has nothing to do with the agreement. Then Mr. Watkins said, "Is it not mentioned in the agreement that the line must be on the South Australian land?" Mr. Groom replied, " That is what I say the agreement strictly seems to contemplate." In the Senate, Senator Best, who introduced the Bill here, affirmed that view, and declared -

quote.para: I wish to point out in this connexion that the route of the railway is not determined according to the terms of the agreement further than that it must be within the east and west limits of the Territory.

speech.para: Senator Givens interjected, " And must end at a given point." That is my view of the terms of the agreement. But that stipulation is rendered a little doubtful by the language of the Bill. I think the agreement in terms makes the point clear, but the Bill itself leaves it a little doubtful.

talk.start.para: - The railway must be strictly within the Territory.

- Yes; but the Attorney-General of the present Government, who is a gentleman of keen mind and an acute lawyer, has made public the opinion, which was adopted - as it was proper that it should be - by the Government in the other House, that such was not the true construction of the agreement. We have also the opinion of the Crown Solicitor of South Australia, which was adopted by the Ministry of last year, and which I myself share. There is, therefore, as pretty an opening for litigation as one could well desire.
- A good thing for the lawyers.

- Good for the lawyers, perhaps, but we are not here as lawyers. We are here as representatives of the different States and of the people of the Commonwealth; and I myself am not going to be a party, now that attention has been called to the doubts that exist, to enacting a measure that may be the cause of a law-suit. We are here to confirm or to disaffirm an agreement, and if we see a possibility of doubt, we ought to do our best to remove it. Consequently, when this Bill gets into Committee, if no one else moves an amendment, I shall do so, in order to make it clear that the railway is to run wholly within the limits of the Northern Territory. I wish to say at once that, unless that be made clear, I shall not support this Bill on its third reading. By allowing these conflicting opinions to remain unsettled, we should simply stultify ourselves as legislators, and put upon the statute-book the initial stage, so to speak, of litigation that will not only produce great difficulty and trouble, but may cause heavy expenditure and unending bitterness between the two contracting parties. We certainly do not desire to do that. All those who vote for the second reading of the measure will, I feel sure, consider that they must vote for my amendment.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: -No.

-If the honorable senator voted for the Bill last year, he must surely vote for my amendment ; because the Bill last year was voted for on the declaration of the Government of the day that the railway was to be wholly within the Northern Territory, and within South Australia.
- The principle of the Bill is that we should consent to taking over the Northern Territory.
- The statement of Mr. Groom last year, as quoted by the honorable senator, was that the South Australian Government contemplated the possibility of the railway going into Queensland territory.
- No; the South Australian Government merely considered the possibility of a deviation. Mr. Groom, in my judgment, was not authorized to make the statement he did.
- Authorized or not, the statement was made.

- The late Government introduced their Bill on the assumption that the railway was to be wholly within the Territory, and my honorable friend voted for the measure on that understanding. He should, therefore, vote on this occasion to make clear what I agree with my honorable friend Senator Gould is at present a little doubtful because of the conflicting opinions to which reference has been made. It is not, I may add, doubtful in my own opinion. I have no hesitation concerning the point, so far as the terms of the agreement itself are concerned. But, unfortunately, the words of the agreement, which make the matter abundantly clear, are not introduced in the Bill. I do not suppose that they were left out by a trick. No one would suggest that for a moment. But this Bill was framed and introduced last year on the assumption that under the strict terms of it the railway was to be wholly within the Northern Territory. Therefore I propose to give honorable senators an opportunity of making that quite clear on the present occasion.
- Does the honorable senator say that there are words in the agreement which are not embodied in the Bill?
- Yes.
- Will the honorable Senator indicate them?
- Certainly. In clause 2, paragraph c, of the agreement, it is provided that the State of South Australia shall -

quote.para: At the time of such surrender authorize by legislation the Commonwealth to do all that is necessary to enable the Commonwealth to make surveys, acquire the necessary lands, and to construct or cause to be constructed a railway in South Australia proper from any point on the Port Augusta railway to a point on the northern boundary line of South Australia proper to connect with that part of the transcontinental railway to be built in the Northern Territory from Port Darwin southwards to the northern boundary of South Australia proper.

speech.para: Those words are not in this Bill.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: - But this is a Bill to ratify the agreement.

- Exactly ; and if my honorable friend will read the valuable opinion given by the Crown Solicitor of South Australia, he will see that he rests upon that point. I am not going to express my own opinion one way or the other. To construe the whole agreement you must look at it as a whole. Those words are in the agreement, and make the intention fairly plain.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: - But if the Bill ratifies the agreement, and those words are in the agreement, surely that is enough?
- But if the point is left in doubt, it may lead to any amount of litigation.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: - The agreement is in the schedule to the Bill.

- If my honorable friend will look at the Bill, he will see that the part of the agreement in which the words quoted occur are omitted altogether from the Bill, because they relate to obligations imposed upon the State of South Australia. Consequently, the words are contained in the Act which has been passed by the South Australian Parliament. This Bill is to ratify and confirm the whole . agreement, and it authorizes the construction of the railway contemplated by paragraph 1 of the agreement. Clause 5 of the Bill says -

quote.para: The agreement is by this Act ratified and approved.

talk.start.para: - That means the agreement set out in the schedule.

- Exactly ; the whole agreement. Then comes clause 14of the Bill, which imposes a liability upon the Commonwealth to do certain things. It is stated in paragraph b of that clause that the Commonwealth is to construct or cause to be constructed a line from Port Darwin southwards ; and in paragraph d the Commonwealth assumes the obligation to construct another railway line. It seems to me to be clear that the. railway to be constructed by the Commonwealth must be within the Territory.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: - I should like to hear the honorable senator arguing on the other side. He would tear the whole thing to pieces.
- It could not be done. The question is not arguable.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir Albert Gould

talk.start.para: -I should be quite willing to hand the honorable senator a brief to argue on the other side.

-I will take the brief and the fee. I appreciate the compliment. But, in order to avoid the possibility of the honorable senator having to hand me, or any one else, a brief in a case between South Australia and the Commonwealth, I think it desirable that the two or three words which I have indicated should be inserted in the Bill. That, therefore, is what I propose to submit by way of amendment. I shall look to Senator Gould for help in elucidating a point that certainly ought to be made clear. Otherwise, the agreement is satisfactory enough. I conclude with the expression of the hope that the Bill will be speedily passed.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Senator Givens) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from12th August (vis page 1477), on motion by Senator McGregor -
That this Bill be now read a second time.

Senator Lt.-Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD (New South Wales) [4.26].-I did not anticipate that this debate would have been resumed this afternoon, and, consequently, I am taken at a disadvantage. It was introduced as a Bill which dealt principally with machinery, but in the form in which it has reached the Senate it contains some very far-reaching provisions which should receive very full and fair consideration at our hands. We all realize, of course, that it is the duty of the Parliament to make our industrial legislation as workable as it can be made, so long as we keep clearly within our constitutional powers. Matters which were discussed and settled on certain lines in 1904 are being entirely altered in this Bill. There is no necessity to debate the position of unions, or the way in which industrial powers should be brought into existence, because we have recognised that it is necessary to enable industrial associations to place their views before the public in the way which they consider desirable in the interests of the community at large. But we are getting more and more into this position : that the. only persons to be considered are those who belong to unions. When an investigation is made, it will be found that the preponderance in number is greatly in favour of the men who do not belong to unions. In introducing the Bill, Senator McGregor pointed out that it is the men of the most ability, the most energy, and of the most far-seeing views who are in the unions, and who have been the means of bringing unionism into its present position. Our people have long since regarded the existence of unions as a very legitimate state of affairs.

talk.start.para: - Not very long.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Yes, unions pure and simple, but not unions which had become to a very large extent political and partisan bodies. It was found that the Sydney Wharf Labourers Union - of which the Attorney-General was secretary - had a rule to the effect that every unionist must contribute a certain sum annually towards a political fund, and, whether he liked it or not, vote for any parliamentary candidate who might be chosen by the Labour party. That, to my mind, was a complete prostitution of the whole intention of unionism as established originally, and as recognised generally by people throughout English-speaking communities. We all recognise that men have the right to combine for the advancement of their' mutual interests, but we do not admit that a few men have the right to procure a strong position with regard to their own particular calling, and to say to men outside their union, " You shall not be admitted unless you are prepared to sacrifice any political principles or views which are not in accordance with those of the governing body." ' The purpose of a trade union, in the first instance, was the protection of the mutual interests of workmen in their own calling. It was recognised that they should have the opportunity of combining to obtain the best practicable conditions from their employers. But the unions had nothing to do with, and never should have been mixed up with,' the political opinions of its members. I can very readily imagine a number of men being in a union, whose object is to get decent working conditions and wages, and at the same time holding different views on political questions. If it were claimed that the men who were selected by the Labour party had only one object in view, and that was to protect the interests of a particular class, there might have been, not a sufficient justification, but some sort of excuse for taking up the position which they did, because they practically said, " We are only concerned with getting Labour interests attended to. Your interests and ours are the same so far as Labour conditions are concerned, therefore we expect you to vote for the man whom the majority of us consider best fitted to represent us in Parliament." But when a man enters Parliament, he has no business to regard himself as the representative of a class. He should look upon himself as a representative of the people, and study the interests of those who do not belong to his class just as he would study the interests of those who do.
- That has been well carried out in the past.

.- What sort of legislation are we called upon to consider from time to time ? To-day we are called upon to deal with a measure relating to industrial matters ; to-morrow we may be asked to consider a measure dealing with trusts ; and on the following day a measure dealing with something else.
- A measure to take over the Northern Territory.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator will find that while there are honorable senators on either side who are opposed on certain principles, their views on other questions agree. Take, for instance, Senator Givens, who supports the Government, and belongs to the Labour party. He and I take the same view in regard to the Northern Territory Agreement, showing at once that we are actuated not by consideration of party, but by a desire to promote the interests of the whole community as represented in this Parliament.
- Are not those who are taking the other side actuated by the same motive?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I recognise, of course, that they are actuated by the same honorable motive, but I contend that men ought to keep themselves free from the suspicion that they only come into Parliament to represent one particular class. It will be remembered that in Sydney a large body of men had preference granted to them by the Arbitration Court. It was found that they had a rule to the effect that no man, unless he would consent to sacrifice his political convictions to those of the dominant majority, should be allowed to enter the union or to earn his livelihood in the occupation which' he was accustomed to follow. Then it became necessary for the Court to make an' order that the rule should be altered if that union was to retain the preference previously granted to it, and the rule was altered accordingly. When the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Bill of 1904 was under consideration, a provision was inserted to protect citizens from being tyrannized over by rules made in this other direction.
- The provision put in the Bill covers everything.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - It covers certain things. But the mast remarkable feature of the provision is what it omits, not what it includes.
- It does not omit anything which the trade unions want.
- It does not go far enough.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Probably the honorable senator. thinks that preference ought to be made compulsory, as was attempted to be done in the first instance.
- I do.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Section55 of the principal Act deals with the question of rules. After making necessary provision for the registration of organizations, it says -

quote.para: Provided that no such organization shall be entitled to any declaration of preference by the Court when and so long as its rules or other binding decisions permit the application of its funds to political purposes, or require its members to do anything of a political character.

And further, provided that no organization shall be entitled to appear before the Court to oppose an application for preference by any organization so long as its rules or other binding decisions permit the application of Us funds to political purposes, or require any of its members to do anything of a political character.

subdebate.1.para: It will be seen that the section deals with employers as well as with employés, and does not extend to organizations having political purposes as a portion of their aims and objects. What the phrase " political purposes " does not include is defined - " Political purposes " in this section does not include obtaining or maintaining provisions applying to all persons in any particular industry, without discrimination as between those who are and those who are not members of an organization, with respect to the regulation of the following matters : - (i.) Preservation of life and limb. (ii.) Compensation for injuries or death. (iii.) Sanitation. (iv.) The sex and age of employees. (v.) The hours of labour. (vi.) The remuneration of labour. (vii.) Protection of salaries and wages. (viii.) Other conditions similarly affecting employment.

It is provided that these organizations shall not be used for political purposes, but the Act specifies certain matters which are of moment in connexion with the employment of workers, and allows to the unions the freest possible hand in those respects. If there are any similar matters which it is necessary to add, then there will be no objection to include them in the section. But why should any organization which is established for the purpose of securing employment, obtaining decent wages and working conditions, and settling industrial disputes, have the right to say, " No man shall come into this union unless he has a particular brand upon him"?

talk.start.para: - Because the people say so.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The people say nothing of the kind. Take any great organization or body of working men. Suppose that 1,000 men are employed in a particular occupation. Many are outside the unions, but the argument which is now urged is that the men who are inside a union may make a close preserve of it for themselves, and say to the other fellows, " You shall not be allowed to work at your trade or occupation, because we have got preference, and before you can come into our body you must give up all your political principles if they differ in any way from those which we advocate at present."
- That is an inversion of the whole matter,

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - You have no right to get rid of provisions of that character, because they were designed to insure the safety of the community at large. I have yet to learn that any man, because he does not see fit to join a union, is not to be allowed to earn his living at the trade or occupation which he has been accustomed to follow.
- Why can he not take the responsibility of going before the Court in the same way as other people?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The responsibility of what?
- There must be some person who takes the responsibility of standing before the Court.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Yes.
- The hundred men do that. They get the privileges and the advantages. The other men enjoy them, but will not come in.
- Order! The honorable senator will have an opportunity to put his views before the Senate.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator has given me a reply which I have often heard. It is said by some persons that if preference is not given to unionists, the chances are that they will be boycotted by employers if they go before the Court. I can see the force of that argument, but I contend that we have no right to go a step further and say that a man who does hot. choose to join a union shall not be allowed to earn his living. If a hundred men in a union go before the Court, and the conditions are such that it is just to give preference to them, well and good ; but you have no business to turn round and say that no other man shall be allowed to engage in that occupation unless he becomes a member of a union if it requires him to support the parliamentary candidate whom it may select.
- That is not correct.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I ask the honorable senator to carry his mind back to the time when the Shearers Union made it a sine qua non of admission to that body that a man should subscribe to a rule binding him body and soul to the parliamentary candidate selected. This preference would have been taken away had not the union seen fit to modify the rule so as to give every decent, respectable man an opportunity of becoming a member of it, quite apart from his political views.
- They did alter the rule.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Yes, but now honorable senators on the other side want a law which will free them from all such difficulties. In the first instance what did they propose in regard to this very Bill ? They brought in a provision that preference should be granted to unionists, thereby taking all discretionary power from the Court. They advocated that if a union applied to the Court to settle certain disputes and troubles which they might have with their employers, preference should be granted to them irrespective of all other considerations. Fortunately the Bill has not come up to the Senate in exactly that form, because it does leave a certain amount of discretion to the Court, although it appears to be limited in a very marked degree. This clause, as originally introduced, provided that the proposed new section 40 should read - "40. The Court, by its award, or by order made on the application of any organization or person bound by the award, may prescribe a minimum rate of wages or remuneration, and in that case shall, on the application of any party to the industrial dispute, or of any organization or person bound by the award -

item.label: (a)
item.para: make provision for fixing, in such manner and subject to such conditions as are specified in the award or order, a lower rate in the case of employees who are unable to earn the minimum wage so prescribed ; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: direct that, as between members of organizations of employers or employees and other persons offering or desiring service or employment at the same time, preference shall be given to such members, other things being equal."

speech.para: As it appears before the Senate, it has been altered in such a way as to leave the granting of preference at the discretion of the Court.

talk.start.para: - Is this the clause which gives the Court power to consider " the welfare of society "?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Yes. Sub-section 2 of the proposed new section 40 reads -

quote.para: Whenever in the opinion of the Court, it is necessary for the prevention or settlement of the industrial dispute, or for the. maintenance of industrial peace, or for the welfare of society, to direct that preference shall be given to members of organizations, as in paragraph a of sub-section1 of this section provided, the Court shall so direct.

speech.para: Under the proposed new section 40, as originally introduced in this Bill, the grant of preference was really left entirely to the sweet will of organizations appearing before the Court, and the Court was given no power to consider whether it was right that an award of preference should be made or not. In the early days of the operation of the Arbitration Act in New South Wales, Mr. Justice Cohen construed the permission to the Court to grant preference into almost a direction from the Legislature that preference should be granted, unless in very exceptional cases.

talk.start.para: - So it ought.
- A very wise interpretation.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Under the section which it is proposed in this clause to repeal, the Court, by its award, may prescribe a minimum rate of wages, and make provision for a lower rate in the case of employes unable to earn the minimum wage, and may also -

item.label: (b)
item.para: direct that, as between members of organizations of employers or employees and other persons offering or desiring service or employment at the same time, preference shall be given to such members, other things being equal ; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: appoint a tribunal to finally decide in what cases an employer or employee to whom any such direction applies may employ or be employed by a person who , is not a member of any such organization.

speech.para: There is some elasticity in the law as it stands to-day, but it would be entirely removed by this Bill, which would prevent the employment of any person who did not belong to an organization where an award of preference had been granted. That is a very important matter, because it is quite possible, though there might not be many such cases, to conceive that a man who, for one reason or another, objected to join an organization, although a very skilful tradesman, might be debarred from employment under the provisions of this Bill, whilst the elasticity of the existing Act would enable his case to be met.
SenatorW. Russell. - I never belonged to a union.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator has never had occasion to belong to one ; he has done remarkably well without belonging to a union. The existing section goes on to say -

quote.para: Provided always that, before any preference to members of organizations is directed as aforesaid, the President shall, by notification published in the Gazette and in such other publications, if any, as the Court directs, specify the industry and the industrial matter in relation to which it is proposed to direct such preference, make known that all persons and organizations interested and desirous of being heard, may, on or before a clay named, appear or be represented before the Court ; and the Court shall in manner prescribed hear all such persons and organizations so appearing or represented.

speech.para: That is another provision which we are here asked to repeal. Under this Bill the Judge of the Arbitration Court is called upon to deal with an industrial dispute from the point of view of the particular organization appearing before him. It may represent 200 or 300 men engaged in an industry which gives employment to 20,000 or 30,000 men. No man who is not a member of the organization appearing before the Court, or employer who is not cited to appear in connexion with the dispute, will have any opportunity of knowing what the organization seeks to obtain, or, if they know, of coming forward to state their views. They would have no locus standi in the Court. I ask honorable senators to say whether it is right or reasonable that men engaged in the great industries of the country should be bound by conditions which will materially affect them when they are given no opportunity to make known their views or submit arguments against the proposal made. I put it to the people of the country whether it is fair that a man should have to be bound by the decision of a Court, come to behind his back, and without his having the slightest knowledge of the conditions proposed to be applied to the industry in which he is engaged.

talk.start.para: - They certainly will not be to his detriment.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - An organization appears before the Court, which can only deal with the claims submitted to it. The President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Court will not be omnipotent, but he would need to be to do justice under this Bill. It has been strongly urged that the President will represent the community generally, but, unfortunately, the general community is about the last body considered by the organization in dealing with these matters. An organization claiming that the cost of living has been increased, appeals to the Court for an increase of wages from10sto 12s. per day. The Court hears the views of the members of the organization, and of a few employers in the industry. It may consider the weight of evidence to be on the side of the organization, and give an award of preference at the rate of pay asked for. But if the whole body of employés and employers engaged in the industry were given an opportunity to make their views known to the Court, and submit the evidence which they could adduce with respect to the conditions of the industry, its expenses, returns and difficulties, the Court might considerably modify the decision come to in their absence. In section 40 of the existing Act there is this further proviso -

quote.para: And, provided further that no such preference shall be directed to be given unless the application for such preference is, in the opinion of the Court, approved by a majority of those affected by the award, who have interests in common with the applicants.

speech.para: This safeguard is to be taken away, and it may be that a dozen men, or a. score, will secure an award of preference against the interests of hundreds engaged in the same industry. Honorable senators opposite profess to believe in majority rule, but, in industrial matters, they are content that a minority appearing before the Conciliation and Arbitration Court should be given the right to bind a majority.

talk.start.para: - But whether the employés are members of the union or not, will not their interests be common ?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - To a certain extent that may be so, but it is not right that an award should be given against the majority of those engaged in an industry. Under the existing Act, in certain circumstances, unionists are entitled to certain privileges, but not at the expense of the whole community, or of all others interested in the same industry.
- The main object sought to be achieved is the prevention of strikes.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - We need not argue that, as we are all agreed that, in a fair and reasonable way, strikes should be prevented, if it be possible to prevent them.
- Will they ever be prevented ?

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - That is quite another question.
- The party on this side are trying hard to prevent them.
- They have not done so yet.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I am afraid that honorable senators opposite have yet much to learn. There is a provision in section 40, of the existing Act, under which, if the Court directs that preference shall be given, it may subsequently suspend or qualify the direction as it thinks fit, if the rules of the organization are burdensome or oppressive, or do not provide reasonable conditions for admission to, or continuance in membership, or if the organization has acted unfairly or unjustly to any of its members in the matter of preference.
- They never do.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Then why repeal this provision of the existing law, if, as the honorable senator says, the organizations have no burdensome or oppressive rules, do not enforce unreasonable conditions of admission to, or continuance in membership, and do not act unfairly to 'any of their members? The honorable senator must have had his ears closed to the statements which have been made on this subject from time to time. The Government are proposing to repeal a law which has hitherto worked fairly and reasonably, and which must commend itself to every unbiased mind. An honorable senator interjected that the object was to put an end to strikes, but, in doing so, all should be treated justly and alike. We could put an end to strikes if we had gaols large enough in which to confine every man who strikes. No honorable senator would contend that that would be a proper way in which to deal with a strike.
- Mr. Wade takes that view.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - He does not ; but I am not concerned about fighting Mr. Wade's battles for him. He is well able to do that himself.
- He needs all the assistance the honorable senator can give him.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - The Government are, in this

speech.para: Bill, proposing to do away with reasonable and proper safeguards. Honorable senators are aware that a work entitled Australia's Awakening has been written and. published by a gentleman who occupies a very prominent position in unionism in this country. The writer gives an extraordinary recipe for the making of good unionists. Honorable senators will, no doubt, recollect the story he relates of a non-unionist desiring to go to work. The first thing the unionists did to him was to duck him. The object was to see whether they could not bring him to understand the value of unionism. When one ducking did not serve, a second was tried; and, after a third ducking, as the writer of the book humorously says, they discovered that the method adopted was an excellent one to impress people with the correctness of the principles of unionism.

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator should give us the other side of the story, if he wishes to be fair.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - Senator Long can do that for himself, later. Will honorable senators contend, in view of the adoption of such a practice, that unions provide reasonable conditions for admission to their organizations ? The provisions of the existing Act at least protect a man's liberty of action to a certain extent.
- Men have not had much liberty of action hitherto.

talker.name: GOULD, Albert
Senator Lt Colonel Sir ALBERT GOULD

talk.start.para: - I think that, on the contrary, the honorable senator must agree that, on some occasions, there has been a great deal of licence, let alone liberty of action, exhibited. I know that one Judge, in reporting upon certain cases that occurred in New South Wales, described the condition of" affairs existing at one time in that State as being practically civil war. The Government are proposing an alteration of the law in connexion with the granting of preference to unionists, and are doing away with the safeguards provided in the existing Act for the protection of men who do not desire to become unionists, and they are further proposing that people may have judgments given behind their backs in matters in which they are directly interested.
